coredata.dc:title: Atomically dispersed nickel species in a two-dimensional molecular sieve: Origin of high activity and stability in dry reforming of methane

coredata.dc:description: Two-dimensional (2D) molecular sieves with highly dispersed nickel species are attractive catalysts for the dry reforming of methane (DRM) because of the ease of molecular diffusion and the deactivation resistance by coke deposition. Here we report the single-step preparation of a 2D nickel silicate molecular sieve with delaminated MWW layers (Ni-DML) by the simple hydrothermal conversion of a borosilicate MWW precursor with nickel nitrate solution. More than 20 wt.% of nickel species were well dispersed in the framework of Ni-DML and the lowest stabilization energy of nickel cluster was calculated using density functional theory calculations. Ni-DML exhibited extremely high conversions of CH4 and CO2 as well as an extraordinary stability, maintaining its activity for 10 days on stream due to the in-situ formation of metallic nickel clusters from the framework species. Ni-DML can be used as a catalyst for DRM without pretreatments such as air calcination and H2 reduction.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Two-dimensional (2D) molecular sieves with highly dispersed nickel species are attractive catalysts for the dry reforming of methane (DRM) because of the ease of molecular diffusion and the deactivation resistance by coke deposition. Here we report the single-step preparation of a 2D nickel silicate molecular sieve with delaminated MWW layers (Ni-DML) by the simple hydrothermal conversion of a borosilicate MWW precursor with nickel nitrate solution. More than 20 wt.% of nickel species were well dispersed in the framework of Ni-DML and the lowest stabilization energy of nickel cluster was calculated using density functional theory calculations. Ni-DML exhibited extremely high conversions of CH4 and CO2 as well as an extraordinary stability, maintaining its activity for 10 days on stream due to the in-situ formation of metallic nickel clusters from the framework species. Ni-DML can be used as a catalyst for DRM without pretreatments such as air calcination and H2 reduction.

ce:section.ce:para: Dry reforming of methane (DRM) has attracted both environmental and industrial attention because it converts the two most harmful greenhouse gases, i.e., CO2 and CH4, into chemical feedstock, i.e., syngas (CO and H2) [1]. DRM is a key technology for building a circular carbon economy, which involves recycling of CO2 into value-added chemicals such as synthetic fuels, methanol, and dimethyl ether and mitigating its emission into the atmosphere [2,3]. However, regardless of its significance in industries and for the environment, the successful commercialization of DRM is challenging because of its endothermic nature (ΔH°298 = 247 kJ mol−1) and complexity of reaction. DRM is associated with several side reactions that generate carbon deposits, such as the Boudouard reaction (2CO ↔ C + CO2, ΔH°298 = −172 kJ mol−1) and methane cracking (CH4 → C + 2H2, ΔH°298 = 75 kJ mol−1), as well as those that reduce the H2/CO ratio in syngas, such as the reverse water-gas shift reaction (RWGS, CO2 + H2 ↔ CO + H2O, ΔH°298 = 41 kJ mol−1) [4]. Thus, the design of a highly active and stable catalyst for DRM is essential for the successful commercialization of this technology.

Among transition metals, Ni has been widely used as an active catalyst because of its low price and high activity [5–10]. To date, studies on Ni-based DRM catalysts have attempted to reduce catalyst deactivation by the deposition of coke and sintering of active metals [11]. Palmer et al. investigated the liquid phase reaction of DRM at high temperatures (>1050 °C) using the molten bimetallic alloy of Ni and In to mitigate coke deposition and metal sintering [12]. Supported Ni catalysts have also been extensively studied to achieve the high dispersion of metallic Ni and retard the adsorption of carbonaceous species [13]. Song et al. reported the high activity and extraordinary stability of a bimetallic Ni-Mo nanocatalyst, which was stabilized at the edges of a single-crystalline magnesium oxide support [14]. Akri et al. reported that atomically dispersed Ni atoms over hydroxyapatite act as an active and coke-resistant catalyst for DRM because they activate only the CH bonds in CH4, preventing its decomposition [15].

The morphology control of the active metal or catalyst support is another decisive factor determining the activity and stability of DRM catalysts [16,17]. A two-dimensional (2D) catalyst structure is advantageous for DRM because of its wide external surface area, which accommodates a large number of active metals with high dispersion and facilitates the diffusion of reactant and product molecules. Kurlov et al. reported the high activity and stability of the 2D morphology of molybdenum oxycarbide for DRM owing to the maximized utilization of active metals [18]. Gao et al. demonstrated similar results using a Ni catalyst supported over 2D hexagonal-boron nitride for DRM [19]. For the same reason, the transformation of three-dimensional (3D) MCM-22 zeolite (framework type MWW) to a delaminated 2D ITQ-2 can facilitate the diffusion of reactant and product molecules, resulting in enhanced catalytic activity [20–22].

MCM-22 is a representative aluminosilicate zeolite having an MWW (MCM tWenty-tWo) structure in which 2D MWW layers with sinusoidal 10-ring (4.1 × 5.1 Å) channels parallel to the x-y plane are connected in the z-axis direction to form 3D large cylindrical supercages (7.1 Å in diameter and 18.2 Å in height) that can be accessible only through another 10-ring (4.0 × 5.5 Å) window [23]. The as-synthesized MCM-22 precursor (MCM-22(P)) prepared by using an organic structure-directing agent (SDA) can be converted to various other zeolitic materials because the 2D MWW layers in MCM-22(P) have not yet formed a complete 3D structure and connected by hydrogen bonds between the hydroxyl groups formed on the external surface of 2D MWW layers. As one of the examples, ITQ-2 having a delaminated 2D MWW structure can be prepared from the MCM-22(P) following the well established procedures, e.g., swelling of MWW layers by surfactants, layer breakage by ultrasonic treatment, and stabilization of surface hydroxyls by hydrochloric acid treatment [20]. However, this complicated synthesis steps make it difficult for the practical commercial applications. In this study, we demonstrated a single-step process for the preparation of a 2D nickel silicate molecular sieve with delaminated MWW layers (Ni-DML) from a layered borosilicate MWW precursor (B-MWW(P)). Ni-DML exhibited high activity and extraordinary stability for DRM because of its large number of in-situ formed metallic Ni species, which are highly dispersed in the external MWW layers.

B-MWW(P) with a Si/B ratio of 9.5 was synthesized using hexamethyleneimine (99 %, Sigma-Aldrich) as an organic SDA following the procedures reported elsewhere [24]. In a typical preparation, hexamethyleneimine and sodium hydroxide (99 %, Sigma-Aldrich) were dissolved in deionized (DI) water, and subsequently boric acid (99.5 %, Junsei) was added at 50 °C. After total dissolution of boric acid, fumed silica (Evonik) was gradually added, and the solution was homogenized. The final solution was transferred into Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclaves and heated at 175 °C for 7 days with agitation (100 rpm). The white solid was recovered by filtration with DI water and dried at room temperature (RT).

Ni-DML was synthesized by the single-step hydrothermal treatment of B-MWW(P) with nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (98 %, Samchun) aqueous solutions with concentrations of 0.25–1.0 M at different temperatures (100–160 °C) for 1–4 days. After the hydrothermal treatment, the solid products were recovered by filtration with DI water and dried at RT. All as-synthesized Ni-DML samples were calcined at 550 °C for 8 h to remove the occluded organic SDA before DRM catalysis, unless otherwise stated. For comparison, 5 wt.% Ni impregnated Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/B-MWW were prepared via an incipient wetness impregnation method using a nickel(II) nitrate aqueous solution. The Ni-impregnated catalysts were dried at 100 °C overnight, and then calcined at 550 °C for 3 h under ambient air.

All the characterization data were obtained from the calcined sample unless otherwise stated. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were measured on a Rigaku SmartLab X-ray diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation in the 2θ range of 3–50 ° (scan rate = 4 ° min−1). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed in air on a Hitachi STA7200 thermal analyzer, where the weight losses related to the combustion of organic SDA and coke were further confirmed by differential thermal analysis (DTA) using the same analyzer. Elemental analysis was carried out on a PerkinElmer OPTIMA 7300DV inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectrometer. The crystal morphology and average size were determined using a Hitachi SU8010 scanning electron microscope (SEM) operating with an accelerating voltage of 15 kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and STEM-EDS high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) images were obtained with an FEI TALOS F200X and an FEI Titan Themis3 Double Cs microscope with chemi STEM Technology operated at 200 and 300 kV, respectively. N2 sorption experiments were performed on a Micromeritics Tristar II analyzer. H2 chemisorption measurements were performed using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. After reduction at 700 °C under a flow of pure H2 for 1 h, the catalyst (0.1 g) was cooled to 35 °C under He, and H2 chemisorption was performed at this temperature. The IR spectra in the structural region were collected on a Shimadzu IRTracer-100 FT-IR spectrometer in ATR mode. UV-DRS was performed using a Shimadzu UV-2600 UV–vis spectrophotometer. The UV absorption spectra were plotted using the Kubelka-Munk function. XPS was performed on a PHI 5000 Versa Probe II with Al-Kα radiation (hν = 1,486.6 eV). The XPS samples were prepared with self-supporting zeolite wafers of approximately 20 mg weight with a 1.3 cm diameter in dry condition. The 29Si MAS NMR spectra were recorded on a 500 MHz Avance III HD Bruker solid state NMR spectrometer at a spinning rate of 5 kHz, a 29Si frequency of 99.36 MHz with a π/2 rad pulse length of 4 μs, a recycle delay of 60 s, and an acquisition of ca. 300 pulse transients. The 29Si chemical shift is reported relative to TMS. The Raman spectra were recorded on a Witec alpha300 Raman-LTPL system using a capillary tube sample holder. The excitation source was the 1064 nm line of a Nd:YAG laser with an intensity of approximately 16 mW at the sample. H2 temperature programmed reduction (TPR) was carried out on a homemade apparatus with a Pfeiffer vacuum Thermo-Star GSD 301 T quadrupole mass spectrometer. A sample of ca. 60 mg was charged in a U-type quartz tube and pre-treated at 550 °C for 2 h under Ar flow with 30 mL min−1. After pretreatment, the catalyst was cooled to RT. Catalyst reduction was then performed by raising the temperature to 850 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under a flow of 5 % H2/Ar at 20 mL min−1. The amount of consumed H2 was calculated from a fragment of H2 signal (m/z = 2). All the spectral decomposition and simulation operations were performed using the Origin 9.0 curve-fitting program.

The DFT calculations were performed in the periodic boundary condition by using DMol3 with Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof of the generalized gradient approximation, as implemented in Materials Studio 7.0 [25–27]. While only the gamma k-point and 4.4 version of DNP basis set were applied, the self consistent field tolerance and maximum angular momentum function were set at 1.0 × 10−6 eV and hexadecapole, respectively. When including Ni atom, the thermal smearing of 0.01 Ha was applied. The convergence tolerances for geometry optimization are follows: energy, 1.0 × 10−5 Ha; max. force, 0.002 Ha Å−1; max. displacement, 0.005 Å. Based on the refined structure of ITQ-1 [28], terminal O atoms formed by removing Si1 atoms were capped by H atoms of a distance of 1.11 Å along the c-axis with ca. 27 Å vacuum region (Fig. S1). The MWW layer structure without Ni (Si68O132(OH)12 per unit cell) was first optimized with symmetry while fully relaxing all atomic positions. Then, on the top side, a framework Ni2+ atom was located at a Si1 site to replace two capping H atoms. After optimizing only the framework Ni and neighboring terminal O atoms while the other atoms were fixed, the expanded region nearby the framework Ni (NiSi6O9H) was relaxed during the geometry optimization. The lowest-energy geometries of neutral Ni n species (n = 1–4) were adopted according to the literature [29]. Likewise, the extraframework Ni species were optimized with the framework NiO2 and subsequently with the NiSi6O9H. The stabilization energy per extraframework Ni atom (SE) is defined as SE = (Ecomplex - Elayer - ENi)/n, where Ecomplex is the energy of the complex at the point where the MWW layer is bound with the Ni n species, Elayer is the energy of the MWW layer, and ENi is the energy of the Ni n species (n: the number of Ni atoms).

The catalytic experiments were carried out under atmospheric pressure in a continuous-flow apparatus with a fixed-bed microreactor. Prior to the experiments, the catalyst was routinely activated under flowing pure H2 (50 mL min−1) at 700 °C for 3 h, purged with N2 (60 mL min−1) at the same temperature for 0.5 h, and kept at the reaction temperature (550–750 °C) to establish a standard operating procedure, allowing time for the reactant/carrier gas distribution to be stabilized. When needed, the reaction proceeded with N2 pretreatment instead of H2. The feed gas stream consisted of CH4, CO2, and N2, which were supplied at rates of 20, 20, and 10 mL min−1, or 60, 60, and 30 mL min−1, respectively, into the reactor containing 0.1 g of catalyst (i.e., gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) = 30,000 or 90,000 mL g-cat−1 h−1). To confirm the influence of methane cracking in DRM, only 40 vol.% CH4 (balanced with N2) was fed into the reactor at 700 or 750 °C and 30,000 mL g-cat−1 h−1 GHSV. The reaction products were analyzed on-line in a Scion 456 gas chromatograph equipped with a Carbosphere 60–80 mesh packed column (1830 × 3.2 × 2.0 mm) and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD), with the first analysis carried out after 10 min on stream. N2 in the feed stream was used as an internal standard to compensate for the changes in concentration due to volume expansion after DRM. The mole balanced conversions and the H2/CO ratios were calculated as follows.
CH4 conversion (%) = {(CH4)in – (CH4)out}/(CH4)in × 100
CO2 conversion (%) = {(CO2)in – (CO2)out}/(CO2)in × 100
H2/CO ratio = [(H2)out/2(CH4)in]/[(CO)out/{(CH4)in + (CO2)in}]

The thermodynamic equilibrium conversions of CH4 and CO2 and variation of the H2/CO ratio with the DRM temperature were determined using Aspen Plus software following the procedures reported elsewhere (Fig. S2) [30]. In this analysis, the RGibbs reactor was used, and five components, i.e., CH4, CO2, CO, H2, and H2O were considered. To analyze the thermodynamic equilibrium composition variation with temperature, the Soave Redlich-Kwong (SRK) equation was chosen to consider the existence of non-ideal gas in the system. All calculations were performed in an isobaric system (1 bar).

The representative Ni-DML- x-y -z was prepared by the single-step hydrothermal treatment of B-MWW(P) at x = 100–160 °C for y = 4 d using z = 1 M nickel nitrate (Ni(NO3)2∙6H2O) solution. As reported by Quyang et al., deboronation and metal substitution using an acidic precursor solution during hydrothermal treatment break the bonds between the layers and lead to the delamination of B-MWW(P) into 2D metallo-silicate layers [31]. As shown in Fig. 1 a, the delamination of B-MWW(P) to 2D Ni-DML was facilitated by the increase of the hydrothermal temperature up to 160 °C. Although the duration (y = 1–4 d) of hydrothermal treatment and the concentration of nickel nitrate aqueous solution (z = 0.25–1.0 M) influenced the degree of delamination, they were less significant (Fig. S3). XRD peaks corresponding to NiO and metallic Ni were not observed in the Ni-DML- x-y -1 samples, indicating the uniform distribution of Ni species. In contrast, Ni-DML-160-4-0.25, Ni-DML-160-4-0.5, and 5 wt.% Ni impregnated B-MWW (Ni/B-MWW) exhibited small XRD peaks corresponding to NiO (111) and NiO (200) at approximately 2θ = 37 ° and 43 °, respectively (Fig. S3). On the other hand, another Ni impregnated Ni/γ-Al2O3 showed the formation of nickel aluminate (NiAl2O4). Although the XRD peaks for γ-Al2O3 and NiAl2O4 are heavily overlapped, the broad envelop at 2θ = 20 ° indicates the formation of NiAl2O4 spinel oxide [32].

The shape of N2 sorption isotherms of Ni-DML catalysts changed from type I microporous to type IV mesoporous characteristics as the values of three synthesis variables increased, indicating the successful transformation of B-MWW(P) to a 2D layered structure (Figs. 1b and S4) [33]. Notably, the adsorption-desorption hysteresis loop of Ni-DML-160-4-1 (Fig. 1b) exhibited the typical interparticle void volume between parallel plates (H3 hysteresis), which is characteristic of delaminated materials [34]. In addition, the external surface areas of the Ni-DML samples continuously increased as the delamination of B-MWW(P) proceeded at higher values of the three synthesis variables (Fig. 1c and Table S1). Furthermore, the decrease of organic contents in the as-synthesized Ni-DML samples prepared at higher hydrothermal temperatures indicated the delamination of B-MWW(P) (Fig. S5).

The exfoliation of MWW layers by hydrothermal treatment was also confirmed by comparing the TEM images of B-MWW and Ni-DML samples prepared at different temperatures. As shown in Fig. 1d, the rigid and angular plate-shaped crystals of B-MWW changed to flexible and thin layers in Ni-DML. Although the MWW layers were not perfectly exfoliated, the separation of significantly thin layers with ca. 1 nm thickness and the presence of external hemi-cages with ca. 1.2 nm diameter were evident in the high-resolution (HR) STEM-EDS HAADF images (Fig. 1e) [20]. Changes in the crystal morphology by hydrothermal treatment were also observed by SEM analysis (Fig. S6). The uniform distribution of a substantial amount of Ni species (ca. 25 wt.%) was observed on Ni-DML-160-4-1 by STEM-EDS analysis (Fig. 1d). As shown in Figs. 1d and S7, the higher the hydrothermal treatment temperature, the higher was the content of Ni species in Ni-DML.

It has been reported that the nickel silicate MFI zeolite has a small Ni cluster inside the MFI channel [35]. Thus, we tried to geometrically optimize the delaminated MWW layer model using a DFT method with a framework Ni2+ atom (NiSi68O132(OH)10 per unit cell). The model was built by removing Si1 atoms and their bridging O1 ones from the refined structure of ITQ-1, i.e., pure-silica 3D MWW zeolite [28]. As shown in Fig. S1, in the optimized framework, the Ni atom was slightly leaned to the two terminal O atoms uncapped by H atoms. In sequence, we performed the optimization of neutral extraframework Ni n species (n = 1–4) that were bound to the framework Ni and neighboring terminal O atoms, and then calculated their stabilization energies (Fig. 3 ). Interestingly, the stabilization energy per extraframework Ni atom is lowest when optimizing monoatomic Ni (−221.7 kJ mol−1), and the energies increased with the number of Ni atoms (Ni2 to Ni4; −122.5 to −91 kJ mol−1). This tendency indicates that the framework nickel of Ni-DML can be stabilized by low numbers (up to ∼2) of extraframework Ni clusters per framework Ni atom (Table 1).

The successful substitution of framework B by Ni in Ni-DML was experimentally confirmed by IR spectroscopy in the region of 400 to 1600 cm−1 (Fig. 2b). B-MWW showed IR absorption bands at 445, 569, 611, 809, 1183, 1243, and 1398 cm−1, which are typical characteristics of the framework vibrations of the MWW structure [36]. When delamination and Ni substitution proceeded at the elevated temperatures, additional bands were observed at approximately 420, 450, 710, and 1020 cm−1 owing to the formation of NiO bonds within the framework of Ni-DML [37–39]. The broad band at approximately 1020 cm−1 in Ni-DML corresponds to the silicate modes of vibration (i.e., SiONi), which is differentiated from the bulk nickel oxides [35,40]. In addition, the band at 1398 cm−1, which corresponds to the vibration peak of SiOB, decreased as the hydrothermal temperatures increased and almost disappeared for Ni-DML-160-4-1. However, the IR spectrum of Ni/B-MWW was similar to that of B-MWW, indicating that the impregnated Ni species interact less with the zeolite framework (Fig. S8).

The framework nickel species in Ni-DML were further confirmed by observation of the narrow UV absorption band at approximately 200–250 nm, which can be attributed to the charge–transfer transitions from oxygen to Ni2+ ions (Fig. 2c). Small shoulders at 250–300 nm were observed in all the Ni-DML samples, and the intensity of the UV absorption band at approximately 200–250 nm increased proportionally with the hydrothermal temperature. Additional bands at approximately 390 and 600–800 nm were observed for Ni-DML-160-4-1, which are typical characteristics of NiO nanostructures [41]. The formation of NiO may have originated from the thermal reduction of nickel nitrate to its hydroxide nanoparticles in a high-temperature (160 °C) hydrothermal environment [42]. In addition, the band at approximately 200–250 nm was not observed for Ni/B-MWW, indicating that most of the nickel species are present in the form of NiO (Fig. S8b).

Fig. 2d shows the HR STEM-EDS HAADF images of the Ni-DML-140-4-1 obtained under different exposure time intervals under a high voltage (300 kV). The formation of ultra-small Ni clusters with diameters less than 2 nm was clearly observed as the exposure time increased. Tables 1 and S1 list the results of H2 chemisorption for the Ni-DML samples pre-reduced with H2 at 700 °C. As the Ni contents of Ni-DML increased, the amount of chemisorbed H2 increased proportionally. However, in the absence of pre-reduction by H2, only 2 μmol g−1 H2 was chemisorbed on Ni-DML-140-4-1, whereas the sample pre-reduced with H2 at 700 °C contained 80 μmol g−1 of chemisorbed H2. The particle size of Ni on pre-reduced Ni-DML-140-4-1 determined by the H2 chemisorption was ca. 10 nm, which is larger than the value (ca. 4 nm) measured by the TEM analysis (Fig. S9). The total amount of Ni used in this calculation was based on the ICP analysis, which is the sum of both metallic Ni and framework Ni. Thus, the real size of metallic Ni calculated from H2 chemisorption should be smaller than 10 nm. These results demonstrate that the Ni species exited the zeolite framework to form the metallic Ni clusters during H2 reduction at high temperature. Thus, catalytically active metal sites with high dispersion can be formed in-situ by treating Ni-DML under reducing conditions.

The surface properties of Ni-DML were characterized by XPS analysis. As shown in Fig. 4 a, the peaks of Ni 2p in Ni-DML were divided into two spin-orbit doublets centered at 873.8–874.2 eV (Ni 2p1/2) and 856.2–856.5 eV (Ni 2p3/2), and their shake-up satellite peaks centered at 880.2 and 862.2 eV, respectively [43,44]. The Ni 2p3/2 peaks centered at 856.2–856.5 eV can be assigned to nickel phyllosilicate (Ni3(Si2O5)(OH)4), which provides strong evidence of framework nickel species in Ni-DML [45–47]. However, the Ni 2p3/2 peak of Ni/B-MWW was split into two peaks centered at approximately 854.5 and 856.5 eV (Fig. S10a). The lower and higher energy peaks correspond to the Ni2+ in NiO and the framework-bound nickel species, respectively, and their relative ratio is approximately 64:36. ΔE Ni-Si, which is the difference between the binding energies of Ni 2p2/3 (Fig. 4a) and Si 2p (Fig. 4b), is a useful indicator that confirms the formation of nickel silicate materials [45–48]. Generally, nickel silicates have ΔE Ni-Si values between 752.8 and 753.8 eV, whereas impregnated Ni species exhibit much lower values. As shown in Table S2, ΔE Ni-Si values of Ni-DML were in the range of 753.0–754.0 eV, indicating that all the Ni species exist in the form of nickel silicate. However, Ni/B-MWW had ΔE Ni-Si values of 753.0 and 751.0 eV, indicating a mixture of nickel silicate and impregnated NiO. Ni/γ-Al2O3 showed a single Ni state centered at approximately 855.8 and 873.5 eV, which is a characteristic of NiAl2O4 spinel. This is in agreement with the observation of the spinel structure in the XRD pattern of Ni/γ-Al2O3 (Fig. S3).

As shown in Fig. 4c, the formation of nickel silicate in Ni-DML was confirmed by 29Si MAS NMR. The bands that appeared between –90 and –100 ppm increased with the hydrothermal temperature due to the formation of external silanol Q2(Si(OH)2) and Q3(SiOH) sites of the 2D MWW layered structure [49]. The band at approximately –105 ppm also increased according to the temperature, possibly owing to the formation of Q4(1Ni), which has a similar chemical shift to Q4(4Si) [50]. Comparing the decomposed spectra of B-MWW and Ni-DML-160-4-1 (Fig. 4d, e), the relative intensity of the band at approximately –110 ppm corresponding to Q4(nB) decreased by deboronation, and the relative intensity of the lower field bands increased. However, in addition to the increase in intensity owing to the external silanols between –90 and –100 ppm by delamination, the increase in relative intensity owing to Q4(mNi) (m ≥ 2) can also be considered in this range. Thus, assuming that the intensities of Q4(2Ni) and Q4(3Ni) at approximately –98 and –92 ppm, respectively, also increase by ∼38 %, which is the increase proportion of Q4(1Ni) at –105 ppm, the Si/Ni of Ni-DML-160-4-1 can be calculated as ∼17, which is similar to the Si/NiFramework values determined by the ICP analysis (Table 1). This implies that the Ni species are dispersed atomically within the framework of Ni-DML. However, a less significant increase of Q4(nNi) bands was observed for Ni/B-MWW (Fig. S10c).

The redox properties of framework nickel species were characterized by performing H2 TPR. As shown in Fig. 4f, no significant consumption of H2 below 600 °C was observed for the Ni-DML samples. The peak temperature and area of TPR profiles increased proportional to the hydrothermal treatment temperature. Ni-DML-160-4-1 exhibited a reduction peak temperature higher than 700 °C, whereas Ni/B-MWW had an H2 consumption peak at ca. 500 °C owing to the reduction of NiO to metallic Ni (Fig. S10d) [6,17]. The Ni species in Ni/γ-Al2O3 were reduced at a temperature higher than 640 °C, which is a characteristic of Ni2+ ions that are not introduced completely in NiAl2O4 spinels [32]. These results indicate that high-temperature treatment above 700 °C is required for the in-situ formation of metallic Ni in Ni-DML catalyst.

The catalytic performance of Ni-DML was evaluated for DRM using a 40 vol.% CH4 + 40 vol.% CO2 feed stream (balanced with N2) with a GHSV of 30,000 or 90,000 mL gcat −1 h−1. As shown in Fig. 5 a, b, Ni-DML-100-4-1 exhibited higher and more stable conversions of CH4 and CO2 at 700 °C compared to Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/B-MWW having a similar amount of Ni (ca. 5 wt.% in Table S1). Considerably faster catalyst deactivation was observed over Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/B-MWW owing to coke deposition. In general, coke formation during DRM is much faster at a lower reaction temperature owing to the enhanced contribution of Boudouard reaction (2CO ↔ C + CO2). The deactivation rates of CO2 conversion over Ni-DML catalysts for 12 h were in the range of 0–1 %, whereas those of Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/B-MWW were 10 and 45 %, respectively (Table S3). The Ni-DML exhibited the highest stability than among the catalysts previously reported in the literature (Table S4).

Both the CH4 and CO2 conversions of Ni-DML catalysts were proportional to the hydrothermal temperature because of the increasing number of Ni active sites (Table 1). With the exception of Ni-DML-160-4-1, all Ni-DML catalysts exhibited a H2/CO ratio of ca. 0.89, which is close to the value obtained at thermodynamic equilibrium at this temperature (Figs. 5c and S2). However, the CH4 conversion and H2/CO ratio for the Ni-DML-160-4-1 catalyst exceeded the thermodynamic equilibrium values. This can be explained by the contribution of catalytic methane cracking, yielding H2 and molecular carbon under the high-temperature DRM condition. Indeed, although the methane cracking by feeding only 40 vol.% CH4 (balanced with N2) without CO2 at 700 °C showed the formation of H2 and coke compounds for both Ni-DML-100-4-1 and Ni-DML-160-4-1 catalysts, the amounts of the latter were larger than those of the former (Fig. S11). This should be due to the larger amount of active metallic Ni sites in Ni-DML-160-4-1, which may induce the higher methane conversion than the thermodynamic value.

The catalytic activities of Ni-DML catalysts at 750 °C were 8–18 % higher than those at 700 °C (Fig. S12a–c). The influence of the hydrothermal treatment period (1–4 d) on the catalytic activity of Ni-DML-160 was less significant (Fig. S12d–f), whereas the lower concentration (0.25 and 0.5 M) of nickel nitrate solution had a detrimental effect on the catalytic performance (Fig. S12g–i). Ni-DML-160-4-0.25 exhibited the lower H2/CO ratios than that of Ni-DML-160-4-1 despite the comparable CH4 and CO2 conversions. This can be explained by the contribution of RWGS under the DRM condition. Indeed, as discussed above, Ni-DML-160-4-0.25 had higher portion of NiO than Ni-DML-160-4-1 (Figs. 1a and S3). This may induce the formation of larger particles of metallic Ni in DRM conditions, which can promote the RWGS [51].

Notably, the Ni-DML-140-4-1 catalyst exhibited extraordinary stability in DRM at 750 °C, and no catalyst deactivation was observed for 10 days on stream (Fig. 5d). Instead, during the reaction, the conversions of CH4 and CO2 increased by 1 or 2% with time on stream, and this may be due to the influence of endothermic side reactions at high temperature, such as methane cracking. The Raman spectra of the used Ni-DML-140-4-1 catalysts after DRM for 12 h and 10 days were compared with that of the fresh catalyst. No Raman band was observed for the fresh catalyst, and the intensity of the Raman bands at 1332 and 2679 cm−1, as well as at 1565 cm−1 (attributed to disordered and ordered graphitic crystallites [52], respectively) for the used catalysts increased with reaction time (Fig. 5e). As shown in Fig. S13a, the XRD peak of graphitic carbon was also detected at 2θ = 26 °, and the coke contents of the fatigue catalysts after 12 h and 10 days were measured as ca. 2 and 6 wt.%, respectively (Fig. S13b and Table S3). The fact that there is no decrease in activity despite the formation of graphitic coke as the reaction time goes by can be attributed to the 2D structural characteristic of Ni-DML catalyst, which has no pore blocking issue due to coke formation unlike the general 3D structural zeolite catalysts. On the other hand, in the powder XRD pattern of the used catalyst, metallic Ni was also observed at ca. 2θ = 44 °, and the framework Ni species decreased, as confirmed by structural IR spectroscopy (Fig. S13c). This indicates that extraframework metallic Ni clusters on Ni-DML are active sites for DRM. From the STEM-EDS analysis (Fig. S13d), it can be seen that Ni particles with average size of ca. 8 nm were still uniformly distributed on the used Ni-DML-140-4-1 catalyst surface even after 10 days of DRM, although this size is twice as large as the average Ni particle size of pre-reduced catalyst (ca. 4 nm in Fig. S9b).

Unlike Ni/γ-Al2O3, which exhibited considerably low initial activity without pre-reduction by H2, Ni-DML-160-4-1 exhibited almost the same catalytic performance regardless of pre-reduction with H2 (Figs. 5f and S12a–c). This can be reasonably explained by the in-situ formation of metallic Ni clusters by the framework Ni species (Figs. 2d and S13d). In addition, the as-synthesized Ni-DML-160-4-1 also showed higher initial CH4 conversion than its calcined analogue (Fig. S14). It thus appears that the catalytic reaction was occurred mainly on a large external surface of 2D Ni-DML rather than on micropores. Notably, when the GHSV was increased to 90,000 mL gcat −1 h−1, the activity of the Ni-DML-140-4-1 catalyst was maintained according to the time on stream at both 700 and 750 °C (Fig. S15). In addition, at 90,000 mL gcat −1 h−1 GHSV, the activity of a single catalyst was maintained at each temperature between 550 and 750 °C in a consecutive reaction run (Fig. S16), while the initial CH4 conversion at 550 °C was ca. 60 % lower than that at 750 °C. The high activity and stability as well as the ease of catalyst handling, such as calcination and pre-reduction, are advantages of Ni-DML catalysts for their practical application in DRM.

2D Ni-DML catalysts were prepared by the single-step hydrothermal treatment of B-MWW(P) with Ni precursor solutions by varying three synthetic variables. Owing to its delaminated nature, Ni-DML had highly dispersed framework Ni sites located on the large external MWW layers. The framework Ni sites were characterized by IR spectroscopy, UV-DRS, XPS, and 29Si MAS NMR techniques, and the in-situ generation of ultra-small metallic Ni particles was monitored by high-voltage STEM-EDS HAADF analysis. Ni-DML-160-4-1 had a large amount of framework Ni, which is the source of highly dispersed active Ni particles formed in-situ during the pre-reduction. Owing to the complex contribution of Ni sites to DRM and methane cracking, Ni-DML-160-4-1 yielded extremely high conversions of CH4 and CO2, which exceeded the thermodynamic equilibrium values. Ni-DML-140-4-1 had extraordinary stability, and no catalyst deactivation was observed during the DRM up to 10 days on stream. In addition, Ni-DML-160-4-1 exhibited its inherent catalytic activity regardless of pre-reduction with H2.
